and then dissolved by 30 mL of deionized (DI) water (18.2 M
under magnetic stirring in a glass beaker. Second, excess NaF and
F with >9 times molar ratio to metal ions (Al
were measured and added into another 30 mL of DI water for
dissolution. Third, the NaF and NH
mL of absolute ethanol was added additionally. At last, after vigorous
stirring for about 30 min, the resultant white suspension was
transferred into a 125 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (Parr
Instrument Company), ﬁlled up to 70% of its capacity, sealed tightly,
C in an electrical furnace for 15 h. After being
slowly cooled to room temperature, the ﬁltered precipitate was
centrifuged several times with DI water to remove any possible ionic
C for 24 h in an ambient atmosphere.
phosphor was pressed into a quarter inch
diameter pellet by using a hydraulic press and then placed in a quartz
ampule which was sealed under vacuum for post-heat treatment. The
ampule was inserted into a furnace and heated from room
cooled to room temperature over 2.5 h. After heating, the ampule was
opened in the air and the pellet was removed. The pellet was ground
in an agate mortar and pestle for several minutes to produce a powder.
The powder was stored with a desiccant after grinding.
Phase identiﬁcation of all the as-obtained
phosphor samples were performed on a Siemens D500 X-ray powder
diﬀractometer (XRD, Bruker AXS Inc., Madison, WI) using Cu K
= 1.5406 Å) radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. XRD patterns were
. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the
respective powder samples were taken by means of the Carl Zeiss
Sigma ﬁeld emission SEM (Carl Zeiss, Carl Zeiss SMT Inc., Peabody,
MA) using the secondary electron detector and operating at an
accelerating voltage of 5.0 kV with a working distance of 8.8 mm.
Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy area scans of the
powder samples were further performed to
determine the elemental composition using an accelerated voltage
of 15 kV and a reduced working distance of 8.5 mm for an aperture of
Steady photoluminescence and excitation spectra were determined
via single photon counting technique on a FSP920 spectrometer
(Edinburgh Instruments, Livingston, UK) equipped with a 450 W
xenon (Xe) lamp, TMS300 monochromators, and thermo-electronic
cooled Hamamatsu R928P photomultiplier tube (PMT) detector.
Time-resolved spectra were measured by time-correlated single
photon counting technique on the FSP920 system with pulsed
signal noise from excitation sources, long-pass ﬁlters of 400, 490, 695,
and 710 nm were appropriately applied in the front of detectors.
were measured by using a Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer (Horiba
Jobin Yvon) equipped with a FL-1073 PMT detector and a SPEX
DM302 P.C. Acq. module. The phosphors were heated on an external
hot plate, and each temperature point was allowed to equilibrate as
monitored by a thermocouple in a sand bath adjacent to the
phosphors. Once the temperature was equilibrated, the emission
spectrum of the hot sample was measured (
compared to a room temperature sample of the phosphor to eliminate
the impact of lamp intensity ﬂuctuations. For comparison, all optical
measurements were rigorously performed under identical conditions
Fluorescence QY of phosphors was measured on a C9220-03
system (Hamamatsu, Bridgewater, NJ) with a 150 W Xe
monochromatic lamp and an integrating sphere. A high-intensity
phosphors. The pink star labels the sharp
